title: 115_hr1848
content: The Act titled "Veterans Affairs Medical Scribe Pilot Act of 2017" establishes a Department of Veterans Affairs Medical Scribe Pilot Program. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will implement a 2-year pilot program to increase the use of medical scribes at 10 Department of Veterans Affairs medical centers, including rural, urban, and areas with a need for improved access or efficiency. The program will hire 20 new term employees as medical scribes and may also enter into contracts with appropriate personnel. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will assign 20 additional medical scribes to 10 medical centers. Two scribes will be assigned to each of two physicians, with 30% in emergency care and 70% in specialty care with long patient wait times. Reports to Congress are required within 180 days. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will assign 20 additional medical scribes to 10 medical centers, with a focus on emergency and specialty care. Reports to Congress on the pilot program's efficiency, patient satisfaction, wait times, and patient volume are required every 180 days. The pilot program under the Secretary of Veterans Affairs will assign 20 medical scribes to 10 medical centers, focusing on emergency and specialty care. Metrics will include patient volume per physician, hiring and training time for scribes, and data analysis for program evaluation. The Comptroller General will submit a report 90 days after the program's termination. The Comptroller General will submit a report to Congress on the pilot program, comparing it to similar private sector programs. Definitions in this section clarify that a medical scribe is an unlicensed individual assisting physicians with electronic health records. The pilot program under this section will be funded using existing Department of Veterans Affairs funds, without the need for additional appropriations. The terms "urban" and "rural" are defined based on rural-urban commuting codes. Prohibition on smoking in Veterans Health Administration facilities. Prohibition on smoking in facilities of the Veterans Health Administration includes no indoor smoking in any facility, except for community living centers until December 31, 2018, and no outdoor smoking in any facility after October 1, 2021. The term 'smoke' encompasses smoking of cigarettes, cigars, pipes, and any other tobacco combustion. The term 'facility of the Veterans Health Administration' refers to any land or building under the Department of Veterans Affairs' jurisdiction and control of the Veterans Health Administration, excluding those under the General Services Administration. A 'community living center' is a Department facility providing nursing home care. The Veterans Health Administration prohibits smoking in its facilities, with a repeal of a specific section from the Veterans Health Care Act of 1992. This section will take effect 90 days after the enactment of the Act. The House of Representatives passed this on July 24, 2017.
